blocks.text:
Hence

\[ \int \sin z \, dz = -\cos x \cdot \frac{\sqrt{a^2 - x^2}}{a} + K. \]

Let

\[ x = a \sin \theta, \quad i.e., \quad dx = a \cos \theta \, d\theta. \]

as before, so

\[ \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{a^2 - x^2}} \, dx = \int \frac{a \cos \theta}{a \cos \theta} \, d\theta = \int d\theta = \theta + C = \sin^{-1} \left( \frac{x}{a} \right) + C. \]

In this case let's set

\[ u = \sin h \, u, \quad i.e., \quad \frac{dx}{du} = \cos h u. \]

Now

\[ \cosh^2 x - 1 = \sinh^2 x \quad (cf. p. 291, Part I) \]

Referring to p. 298, Part I, we see that

\[ \int \text{sech}^2 u \, du = \tanh u + C \]
